Award.AwardTitle: Interaction of Environment, Locomotion and Sensor Structure Determines Odor-tracking Behavior.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Most animals locate resources critical to their survival and reproduction (i.e., food, mates) by tracking evaporated odors that have moved downwind away from these resources in odor plumes. A major unanswered question about this remarkable behavior is how animals maintain contact with odor plumes. Do they: 1) make simultaneous side-to-side comparisons of odor levels between odor sensors, or 2) compare a series of odor concentrations detected at different points along their paths? This answer is not known because the multiple variables that affect an animal?s behavioral response to odor have rarely been studied in a systematic way. These variables include a dynamically changing environment, how fast they are walking, flying or swimming, and odor sensors on different parts of their bodies.
Our project will use a novel integrative approach to address this long standing question and transform and expand our understanding of odor-guided behavior. The behavioral responses of flying and walking animals will be compared as the three variables listed above are manipulated. The variables most important to successful source location will be identified along with how they interact with each other. The knowledge gained about biological control rules and their interaction with the behavior and sensory structures of a specific organism will reveal how animals prioritize information to adapt their behavior to unpredictable conditions.
The broader impacts of this study will include: 1) research training for students from our university and from a local all-girls high school, 2) training for a Cleveland Metropolitan High School teacher who will work in our lab during summers with the goal of using insect behavior as a tool to bring experience-based learning to the classroom, and 3) knowledge of biological control rules for odor tracking to apply to such projects as odor-tracking behaviors in mobile robots.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Different kinds of insects have differently shaped odor-detecting antennae and track odors walking slowly or flying rapidly through different environments that alter odor distribution in unique ways. Thus, insects are ideal animals to reveal how these three variables interact to structure their odor tracking behavior. We used three species: the American cockroach, which is an excellent walker, the Tobacco hornworm moth, which is a superb flier, and the oriental fruit moth, which tracks odors while flying and walking.

 

Our first series of experiments compared the odor tracking behavior of walking cockroaches to flying moths that were challenged to locate an odor source in both a "roach-like" and "moth-like" environment. In the roach-like environment the wind speed was slow, while the wind in the moth-like environment was three times faster. Turbulence varied from low to high in both environments. Both species performed best in conditions similar to where they live in nature. Walking cockroaches performed well in low wind-low turbulence conditions, while flying moths performed well in high wind speed-relatively turbulent conditions. Apparently their brains and controllers are "tuned" to their bodies and the environments in which they live.

 

Do our study insects compare the levels of odor detected on each antenna instantaneously, or do they sum them and compare sums over time? This question is typically asked by comparing the odor tracking behavior of intact insects to those with one antenna surgically removed. If they steer by comparing across their antennae and turning toward the highest concentration, removing one antenna should cause them to always steer toward the intact antenna. Because cockroaches may have a "map" in their brains of the location of odor sensors along the length of their antenna, we chose to experimentally alter their antenna differently. We made the typical comparison of tracking behavior between an intact and one-antennaed cockroach. In addition, we compared odor tracking behavior of cockroaches with progressively shorter antennae, removing fractions of the length of one or both antennae. None of our experimentally manipulated cockroaches looped or turned toward their intact antennae. They continued to express similar looking odor tracking behavior, but located the odor source less often as their antennae got shorter. It also did not matter if the antennae were symmetrically or asymmetrically shortened. Success at locating the source depended on the total length of antenna remaining after our manipulations. We proposed that the cockroaches may have a map of their odor world corresponding to the total length of their antennae. Their odor tracking performance degrades because the decreasing spread of their antennae decreases their "view" of their odor world. We tested this idea with a computer simulation model whose results are consistent with the performance of our cockroaches.

 

Finally, we wanted to know if a flying insect changed the way it tracks an odor plume when it lands walks up the plume. For these experiments we challenged oriental fruit moth males to track a plume of female sex attractant upwind while flying and then land and continue tracking the same plume while walking. It is thought that flying moths moving rapidly through the odor plume adapt their behavior using the sum of odor detected on both antennae compared from moment to moment. Since walking moths move through the odor much more slowly, they could use bilateral comparisons between their two antennae. We compared plume tracking performances and the flying-walking transitions between intact control moths and those with one antenna surgically removed. Flying plume tracking moths with one antenna behaved the same as those with both antennae. Their behavior changed dramatically when they landed and continued tracking the plume. Moths with both antennae walked almost straight up the plume, while about half the moths with only one antenna landed and began to walked up the plume looping toward the intact antenna (i.e., a moth with an intact right antenna turned to the right and the same for the left). Exactly the behavior expected if the moths were turning toward the highest concentration. The moths with only one antenna all reached the odor source. The change in tracking behavior shown by about half of our experimental population indicates the moths changed the way they were using the odor information when they landed.

 

This grant supported, a high school teacher from the Cleveland Metropolitan School District to work in my lab during the summer, two undergraduate researchers who each presented their results at national scientific meetings, and two high school students from the Cleveland Metropolitan School District. The high school teacher developed 12 different laboratory exercises using insects. We have, and continue to, provide him insects from our laboratory colony for his use in his high school classroom. I continue to collaborate with engineers who are working to use control rules we learn from our insect experiments to control mobile plume tracking robots.
